00104     virtual ~EGS_BaseGeometry();
00105 
00119     inline bool isConvex() const { return is_convex; };
00120 
00126     virtual int inside(const EGS_Vector &x) = 0;
00127 
00134     virtual bool isInside(const EGS_Vector &x) = 0;
00135 
00143     virtual int isWhere(const EGS_Vector &x) = 0;
00144 
00153     static int findRegion(EGS_Float xp, int np, const EGS_Float *p) {
00154         int ml = 0, mu = np;
00155         while( mu - ml > 1 ) {
00156             int mav = (ml+mu)/2;
00157             if( xp <= p[mav] ) mu = mav; else ml = mav;
00158         }
00159         return  mu - 1;
00160     };
00161 
00192     virtual int howfar(int ireg, const EGS_Vector &x, const EGS_Vector &u,
00193                    EGS_Float &t, int *newmed=0, EGS_Vector *normal=0) = 0;
00194 
00207     virtual EGS_Float howfarToOutside(int ireg, const EGS_Vector &x,
00208             const EGS_Vector &u);
00209 
00220     virtual EGS_Float hownear(int ireg, const EGS_Vector &x) = 0;
00221 
00226     virtual EGS_Float getMass(int ireg) { return 1.0; }
00227

00234                  return 0.0;
00235     }
00236 
00242     virtual int getNRegDir(int idir) { return 0; }

00250     int regions() const { return nreg; };

00259     virtual bool isRealRegion(int ireg) const {
00260         return (ireg >= 0 && ireg < nreg);
00261     };
00262 
00269     virtual int medium(int ireg) const {
00270         return region_media ? region_media[ireg] : med;

00502     virtual bool hasBooleanProperty(int ireg, EGS_BPType prop) const {
00503         if( !bp_array ) return ( prop & bproperty );

00983 /* \example geometry/example1/geometry_example1.cpp
00984 
00985   Suppose that you frequently use the same complex geometry and you
00986   are tired of always having to include the long definition of this geometry
00987   into your input file. In this case it may be worthwhile to implement your
00988   own geometry DSO that constructs the geometry of interest with very little
00989   input (or even no input at all). This example illustrates how to do this
00990   programatically.
00991 
00992   As this is just an example, the geometry we will be constructing is not very
00993   complex: it consists of a cylinder inscribed in a sphere and the sphere
00994   inscribed in a box as shown in the figure ???. We want to be able to define
00995   the media of the cylinder, the sphere and the box in the input file
00996   (so that we can easily use different PEGS data sets, for example). All other
00997   dimensions of our example geometry are fixed.
00998 
00999   To create our new geometry, we make a new subdirectory in the egspp
01000   geometries subdirectory called \c example1. To be able to use the
01001   predefined rules for building geometry libraries we create a dummy
01002   header file \c %geometry_example1.h that does nothing else except to
01003   define the \c EGS_EXAMPLE1_DLL
01004   macro:
01005   \include geometry/example1/geometry_example1.h
01006   and put the implementation in \c %geometry_example1.cpp.
01007   \dontinclude geometry/example1/geometry_example1.cpp
01008   In this file we include the just created header file and the EGS_Input
01009   class header file to get access to its definition,
01010   needed in the \c %createGeometry() function (see below):
01011   \until egs_input
01012   We also need the declarations of the various geometry classes that we
01013   will use to construct our geometry:
01014   \until egs_envelope_geometry.h
01015   We then define the dimensions of the various geometrical structures
01016   \until box_size
01017 
01018   The remaining task is to implement a C-style \c %createGeometry() function
01019   exported by the DSO
01020   \until EGS_EXAMPLE1_EXPORT
01021   We check that the input object is valid and return \c null if it is not
01022   \until }
01023   We then look for a definition of the cylinder medium and print a warning if
01024   such a definition is missing:
01025   \skipline cyl_medium
01026   \until }
01027   We repeat basically the same code to obtain the sphere and the box
01028   media
01029   \until }
01030   \until }
01031   and return \c null if any of the media definition was missing:
01032   \until if
01033   Now we are ready to construct our geometry. We first create a set of
01034   parallel z-planes
01035   \until EGS_ZProjector
01036   As the planes will only be used by our geometry object internally, we don't
01037   care how the plane set is named and therefore give it a name using
01038   the static function EGS_BaseGeometry::getUniqueName().
01039   In a similar way we create a set of z-cylinders consisting of a single
01040   cylinder
01041   \until ZProjector
01042   and make a closed cylinder modeled as a 2D-geometry from the planes and the
01043   cylinder surface:
01044   \until getUniqueName
01045   We then set the medium of the cylinder
01046   \until setMedium
01047   The next step is to create the sphere as a set of spheres consisting of
01048   a single sphere
01049   \until getUniqueName
01050   and to fill it with the sphere medium defined in the input
01051   \until setMedium
01052   We then use an envelope geometry to inscribe the cylinder into the just
01053   created sphere:
01054   \until getUniqueName
01055   The next step is to create the outer box and fill it with the box medium
01056   defined in the input
01057   \until setMedium
01058   (as our geometry will always be centered about the origin, we pass a
01059    \c null affine transformation to the constructor of the box).
01060   We now inscribe the \c the_sphere geometry object (which is the sphere
01061   with the cylinder inscribed in it) into the just created box using
01062   again an envelope geometry,
01063   \until the_box
01064   set the name of \c the_box from the input using the inherited
01065   \link EGS_BaseGeometry::setName(EGS_Input*) setName() \endlink method,
01066   \until setName
01067   and return a pointer to the just created geometry
01068   \until }
01069   \until }
01070   That's all.
01071 
01072   In the Makefile we include the egspp make config files,
01073   \dontinclude geometry/example1/Makefile
01074   \skipline EGS_CONFIG
01075   \until my_machine
01076   set the C-preprocessor defines to the standard set of defines
01077   for our egspp configuration,
01078   \until DEFS
01079   define the name of our DSO,
01080   \until library
01081   and and the set of files needed to build the DSO
01082   \until lib_files
01083   Because we are using planes, cylinders, spheres, a ND-geometry, a box
01084   geometry and an envelope geometry to construct our geometry, we must
01085   link against the geometry libraries containing these geometries.
01086   We accomplish this by seting the \c link2_libs make variable to the
01087   list of needed libraries
01088   \until egs_genvelope
01089   We then include the standard rules for building a DSO
01090   \until include
01091   and set the dependencies of our object files
01092   \until make_depend
01093   We must also add the dependencies on the various geometry header files
01094   that we are including
01095   \until egs_envelope_geometry.h
01096   We can now build our geometry DSO by typing \c make and use
01097   it by including input like this in the input file
01098   \verbatim
01099   :start geometry:
01100       library = geometry_example1
01101       name = some_name
01102       cylinder medium = H2O521ICRU
01103       sphere medium = AL521ICRU
01104       box medium = AIR521ICRU
01105   :stop geometry:
01106   \endverbatim
01107   It is worth noting that we could have constructed this geometry as the
01108   \link EGS_UnionGeometry union \endlink of the cylinder pointed to
01109   by \c the_cyl, the sphere pointed to by \c sphere and the
01110   box pointed to by \c box. However, such an implementation would be
01111   much slower at run time because for each invocation of a geometry
01112   method the union will have to interogate the geometry methods of all
01113   3 objects. In contrast, the envelope geometry will be checking only
01114   against the box for points outside of the box, the box and the sphere for
01115   points inside the box but outside the sphere, the sphere and the cylinder
01116   for points inside the sphere but outside the cylinder and the cylinder
01117   only for points inside the cylinder.
01118 
01119   The complete source code of this example geometry is below
01120   \include geometry/example1/Makefile
01121   \include geometry/example1/geometry_example1.h
01122 
01123 */
01124 
01125 /* \example geometry/example2/geometry_example2.cpp
01126 
01127   This example illustrates how to create the same geometry as
01128   described in
01129   <a href="geometry_2example1_2geometry__example1_8cpp-example.html">
01130   this example</a> but using EGS_BaseGeometry::createSingleGeometry
01131   to create the geometry from definitions stored in an EGS_Input objects.
01132   The header file is similar as in the previous
01133   <a href="geometry_2example1_2geometry__example1_8cpp-example.html">
01134   example</a>, but unlike in the previous example we don't need the
01135   header files of the various geometries being used.
01136   Our implementation consists of a single C-style function
01137   \c %createGeometry()
01138   \dontinclude geometry/example2/geometry_example2.cpp
01139   \skipline createGeometry
01140   As with the previous
01141   <a href="geometry_2example1_2geometry__example1_8cpp-example.html">
01142   example</a>, we check for valid input and extract the
01143   media of the cylinder, sphere and the box from the input
01144   \until !ok
01145   We will create the various geometry objects needed in our composite
01146   geometry by passing EGS_Input objects containing geometry definitions
01147   to the EGS_BaseGeometry::createSingleGeometry function.
01148   We start with the set of planes needed to close the cylinder.
01149   We first create an EGS_Input object named \c geometry that we will
01150   be passing to the geometry creation function:
01151   \until plane_input
01152   We then create properties for the library name,
01153   \until plane_library
01154   the plane-set type,
01155   \until plane_type
01156   the name of the set of planes,
01157   \until plane_name
01158   and the plane positions
01159   \until plane_positions
01160   and add them to the geometry definition
01161   \until plane_positions
01162   We then create the set of planes
01163   \until createSingleGeometry
01164   The definition and creation of the set of cylinders is very similar
01165   \until createSingleGeometry
01166   We now make a closed cylinder as a 2D geometry
01167   \until createSingleGeometry
01168   and set its medium
01169   \until setMedium
01170   In a similar fashion we create the sphere, use an envelope geometry
01171   to inscribe the cylinder into the sphere, create a box, and use again
01172   an envelope to inscribe the sphere into the box. The code is not shown
01173   here as it is lengthy and boring but can be found at the end of this page.
01174   Finally we set the name of the newly created geometry \c the_box and
01175   return it:
01176   \skipline the_box->setName
01177   \until }
01178   \until }
01179 
01180   The Makefile is now simpler as we don't need to link against the
01181   various geometry DSOs as they are loaded dynamically at run time
01182   by the EGS_BaseGeometry::createSingleGeometry function and
01183   our implementation also does not depend on the header files of the
01184   various geometry classes being used:
01185   \include geometry/example2/Makefile
01186 
01187   For completeness here is the header file:
01188   \include geometry/example2/geometry_example2.h
01189   and the complete implementation:
01190 */
01191 
01192 
01193 #endif
